Jest & LWC


This work fits more so into the 'what I have done for fun' category than a full blown project. I had the great opportunity to put together a presentation to the Johnson & Johnson Salesforce engineering and leadership team on April 1st, 2020 on the current landscape of tools for testing a typical Salesforce project. Presentations were given on Apex testing, Robot framweork test automation, and using Jest to test frontend Lightning Web Components (my section).


Prior to the research I did for the presentation, I would say I had a fairly good grasp on how to use Jest to write a good unit test for a LWC. However, this opportunity really let me dive deeper into what was going on under the covers. Especially into the functions and capabilities of the @salesforce/sfdx-lwc-jest package.


Seeing as it was a presentation on Jest testing LWC, it seemed fit to present the topic with LWC. You can view the presentation I gave on this simple one page public community: https://lwc-jest-developer-edition.na111.force.com/s/. Although most of the information you will find on the site will be shortened bulleted points which I expanded on during the presentation itself - the core concepts are there, and you can interact with the Addition component which was demoed as an example.


I even have packaged the code into a state where you could pull down the code yourself and push it to your own scratch org: https://github.com/matthewdoles/lwc-jest


After giving this presentation, I was eventually even charged with integrating a Jest testing stage into our Salesforce specific Jenkins pipeline at Johnson and Johnson. While I provivded the subject matter expertise on LWC Jest testing, I worked with our releasae manager who actually dug into the .groovy file and got the pipleline configured. Essentially, since our jobs were already using a Docker environment with SFDX installed, we are abale to use SFDX commands to install the @salesforce/sfdx-lwc-jest package on the fly and execture the tests.
